thread.title: Reggie Yates, Adam Lambert and Lorraine Kelly win at Attitude Pride Awards
thread.title_full: Reggie Yates, Adam Lambert and Lorraine Kelly win at Attitude Pride Awards

title: Reggie Yates, Adam Lambert and Lorraine Kelly win at Attitude Pride Awards
text:
Reggie Yates, Adam Lambert and Lorraine Kelly win at Attitude Pride Awards Reggie Yates, Adam Lambert and Lorraine Kelly win at Attitude Pride Awards Share 
Presenter Reggie Yates was honoured for his BBC Three documentary Extreme Russia at the Attitude Pride Awards. 
Reggie collected the Ally gong at London’s Banqueting House where celebrities and VIPs gathered for the annual awards. 
His show exposed the hatred and violence faced by the country’s LGBT citizens. For his moving documentary 'Extreme Russia', our Ally Award 2015 goes to @REGYATES ! http://t.co/Wl8JHqjpmq pic.twitter.com/a3UNkhUaRs 
— Attitude (@AttitudeMag) October 14, 2015 
Newsnight presenter Evan Davis was named man of the year and Cyril Nri picked up the actor of the year award. Fashion designer Alexander McQueen was also recognised posthumously with Attitude’s Legend Award – collected by his sister Jacqueline. 
Others honoured on the night included Adam Lambert who scooped the Music Award and who also performed at the event. 
— Attitude (@AttitudeMag) October 14, 2015 
One person who did miss out on the action was One Direction’s Liam Payne, although he did win the sexiest man of the year award. Gutted I can't make the @AttitudeMag awards tonight as I'm sure it's going to be an amazing evening 
Ireland’s Yes voters in the referendum on same-sex marriage won the greatest moment of the year while the media recognition award went to The X Factor. The TV personality of the year was Antony Cotton. (Jonathan Brady/PA) 
To celebrate the Awards, Attitude magazine has launched eight exclusive winners’ covers and interviews. They are available to download and in shops from October 15. 
Matthew Todd, editor of Attitude magazine said: “We’re absolutely delighted to recognise such a wide variety of winners, all of whom have shaped the world of our readers, both gay and straight, trans and cisgendered. 
“We’re delighted to honour the legendary April Ashley MBE with an ICON Award. She is a woman who was living in truth and dignity long before the growing understanding of trans peoples needs that we have finally begun to see. It’s an honour for us to be able to celebrate her with this award and a special cover.” Our second Icon Award of the night goes to the legend and pioneer that is April Ashley http://t.co/qldy1dwjc0 pic.twitter.com/ysBUCRrWf5 
Guests included Mark Gatiss, Boy George, Sir Ian McKellen and Michelle Collins. Kiegan Hirst collected the editor’s special award at the show hosted by Ana Matronic of the Scissor Sisters. (Jonathan Brady/PA)
